content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may be cited as the Act. It includes an FMAP adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" increases the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on estimated compact migrant expenditures. The chief executive official must submit expenditure estimates to the Secretary of the Interior for review before each calendar quarter. The affected jurisdiction submits estimated compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior for review. The Secretary of the Interior adjusts the estimation and sends the final amount to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of HHS estimates the FMAP increase needed for each jurisdiction for a calendar quarter. The Secretary of HHS estimates the FMAP increase needed for each affected jurisdiction to result in an increase in Federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act, without exceeding limitations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates the FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions to ensure Federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act do not exceed set limitations. Notifications are sent to chief executive officials 30 days before the quarter begins. Reconciling and payment adjustments are reported by affected jurisdictions each quarter with an FMAP increase. The chief executive official of the affected jurisdiction must submit an accounting of migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior for each quarter with an FMAP increase. The Secretary of the Interior reviews the accounting submitted for reconciliation and payment adjustments. The chief executive official of the affected jurisdiction submits quarterly migrant expenditure accountings to the Secretary of the Interior for review and adjustments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services then reviews the FMAP increase impact on Federal payments to the jurisdiction. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews the FMAP increase impact on Federal payments to affected jurisdictions and makes adjustments for future quarters. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will adjust the FMAP for affected jurisdictions to account for overpayments or underpayments resulting from the increase in FMAP. The FMAP for a jurisdiction cannot exceed 100 percent, and compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The FMAP for affected jurisdictions cannot exceed 100 percent, and compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Definitions include "affected jurisdiction" and "compact migrant expenditures." The term "compact migrant expenditures" refers to non-Federal funds spent by affected jurisdictions for services for qualified nonimmigrants, including related administrative costs and payments to healthcare providers. The Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016 defines "compact migrant expenditures" as costs incurred by affected jurisdictions for healthcare services provided to qualified nonimmigrants, excluding payments made under a State plan or from other Federal funds. The Act also amends the Federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) as defined in the Social Security Act. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS FOR ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include educating alien children from Freely Associated States and payments for eligible federally connected children residing in the United States. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes educating alien children from Freely Associated States and additional funds for eligible federally connected children residing in the United States. The amendment adds a provision for children from the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau, and allows for a multiplier factor for these children. The amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 authorizes additional funds of $10,000,000 annually for federally connected children, with a provision to multiply the number of children from Freely Associated States by a factor of 1.25. SEC. 4 amends the Housing and Community Development Act to give preference to U.S. citizens or nationals over aliens for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 5 calls for an independent assessment of the strategic relationship between the U.S. and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State will seek an agreement with an organization to assess the strategic importance of the US relationship with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. This assessment will include the relationships as part of the Asia-Pacific re-balance and the capabilities of US agencies in administering the Compact of Free Association. The assessment will include the strategic importance of the US relationship with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau in the Asia-Pacific region. It will evaluate the capabilities of US agencies in administering the Compacts of Free Association and provide recommendations for improvements and future administration. The eligible organization will provide support and recommendations for improvements to the Republic of Palau, including changes to processes or organizations as needed. They will also make recommendations for the renewal and future administration of Compacts and financial support. A report including the assessment and other relevant matters must be submitted to the Secretary of State within one year of the enactment of the Act. The eligible organization entering into an agreement must submit a report to the Secretary of State within one year of the Act's enactment. The report should include the required assessment, specified matters, and any additional relevant information deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The report must be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex if necessary. The organization may obtain official data directly from US departments or agencies to fulfill the requirements of the agreement.
